title: David Theobald
text:
David John Theobald (born 15 December 1978) is an English retired semi-professional <a href="Association%20football">football</a> <a href="Defender%20%28association%20football%29">defender</a> who played in the <a href="Football%20League">Football League</a> for <a href="Brentford%20F.C.">Brentford</a>, <a href="Swansea%20City%20A.F.C.">Swansea City</a> and <a href="Cambridge%20United%20F.C.">Cambridge United</a>. He played the majority of his career in <a href="non-league%20football">non-league football</a>, predominantly for <a href="Cambridge%20City%20F.C.">Cambridge City</a>, for whom he made over 270 appearances across three spells. He is currently first team <a href="Coach%20%28association%20football%29">coach</a> at Cambridge City.
Career.
Early years.
A <a href="Defender%20%28association%20football%29">defender</a>, Theobald began his career in the <a href="youth%20system">youth system</a> at <a href="Cambridge%20United%20F.C.">Cambridge United</a>, before joining the youth setup at <a href="Ipswich%20Town%20F.C.">Ipswich Town</a>. He progressed to undertake a scholarship, but did not win a call into a first team squad before his release at the end of the <a href="1998%E2%80%9399%20Ipswich%20Town%20F.C.%20season">1998–99</a> season.
Brentford.
On 8 July 1999, Theobald signed a three-year contract with newly promoted <a href="Football%20League%20Second%20Division">Second Division</a> club <a href="Brentford%20F.C.">Brentford</a> on a <a href="Free%20transfer%20%28association%20football%29">free transfer</a>. He was utilised as cover for injuries and had a run in the team as a stand-in <a href="right%20back">right back</a> for the injured <a href="Danny%20Boxall">Danny Boxall</a> during the <a href="1999%E2%80%932000%20Brentford%20F.C.%20season">1999–00</a> season and in <a href="Central%20defender">central defence</a> for <a href="Scott%20Marshall%20%28footballer%29">Scott Marshall</a> during <a href="2000%E2%80%9301%20Brentford%20F.C.%20season">2000–01</a>. Theobald was named in the starting lineup for the <a href="2001%20Football%20League%20Trophy%20Final">2001 Football League Trophy Final</a> and received a runners-up medal. He was released after Brentford's defeat in the <a href="2002%20Football%20League%20Second%20Division%20play-off%20Final">2002 Second Division play-off Final</a> and made just 37 appearances during three seasons at <a href="Griffin%20Park">Griffin Park</a>.
Swansea City.
On 26 July 2002, Theobald signed a one-year contract with <a href="Football%20League%20Third%20Division">Third Division</a> club <a href="Swansea%20City%20A.F.C.">Swansea City</a> on a free transfer. He made just 12 appearances before leaving the <a href="Vetch%20Field">Vetch Field</a> in February 2003.
Cambridge United.
On 7 February 2003, Theobald joined hometown Third Division club <a href="Cambridge%20United%20F.C.">Cambridge United</a> on a contract running until the end of the <a href="2002%E2%80%9303%20Football%20League%20Third%20Division">2002–03</a> season. He made just one appearance before his contract expired.
Non-league football.
Between 2003 and 2018, Theobald had a long career in <a href="non-league%20football">non-league football</a>, predominantly with <a href="Cambridge%20City%20F.C.">Cambridge City</a>, for whom he made 274 appearances and scored 39 goals across three spells. He also played for <a href="Canvey%20Island%20F.C.">Canvey Island</a>, <a href="Kettering%20Town%20F.C.">Kettering Town</a>, <a href="St%20Albans%20City%20F.C.">St Albans City</a>, <a href="Royston%20Town%20F.C.">Royston Town</a>, <a href="Soham%20Town%20Rangers%20F.C.">Soham Town Rangers</a> and <a href="Bishop%27s%20Stortford%20F.C.">Bishop's Stortford</a>.
Managerial and coaching career.
Soham Town Rangers.
On 8 October 2015, Theobald and fellow senior player Robbie Nightingale took over as joint-managers of <a href="Isthmian%20League">Isthmian League</a> First Division North club Soham Town Rangers. He remained in the role until 4 December 2016, when he followed Nightingale out of the club.
Cambridge City.
On 5 December 2016, Theobald returned to <a href="Southern%20Football%20League">Southern League</a> Premier Division club Cambridge City as first team coach.
Personal life.
Theobald attended <a href="Impington%20Village%20College">Impington Village College</a>. He is a <a href="Liverpool%20F.C.">Liverpool</a> and <a href="Cambridge%20United%20F.C.">Cambridge United</a> supporter.
Honours.
Canvey Island
Cambridge City
